Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2017 ACM Workshop on Mobile Computing Systems and Applications (HotMobile)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support students at U.S. institutions to attend the Workshop on Mobile Computing Systems and Applications (ACM HotMobile 2017). HotMobile, sponsored by ACM SIGMOBILE, will be held in February, 2017 in Sonoma, CA. HotMobile 2017 is an important workshop targeting mobile computing and system integration fields and attending this event will benefit the scientific progress of the student's research. The exposure to the technical content of HotMobile 2017 will inspire students to address the tough problems in their respective fields, with a long-term benefit of scientific advances in these types of networks.

Priority will be given to students who will benefit from attending this workshop, but are unlikely to attend due to the unavailability of travel funding. In addition, applications from female and underrepresented groups in networking research will be strongly encouraged. Up to fourteen students will receive travel grants from this award to attend HotMobile 2017.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this award was to broaden participation in the ACM Workshop on Mobile Computing Systems and Applications (HotMobile) 2017 by enabling greater student participation. In particular, we sought to increase the number of under­represented student attendees, including female students, under­represented minorities (URMs), undergraduates, and first time attendees. HotMobile provides a high caliber forum to present innovative and significant research on the design, implementation, usage, and evaluation of mobile systems, applications, and services. The research and development results reported in HotMobile workshops span multiple disciplines, including wireless communication, mobile applications, wearable computing, vehicular wireless systems, personal area networks, operating systems, distributed algorithms, data management, scheduling, sensors, security and privacy. HotMobile seeks to provide a cross­-disciplinary venue for researchers addressing the design of mobile computing in the context of an integrated system. 

Through an open solicitation process that advertised the availability of travel grant funds on multiple websites and email distribution lists, we received 17 student applications.  We were able to provide travel support for 14 students to attend HotMobile 2017, including 12 first time attendees.  HotMobile provided a collegial atmosphere and actively fostered discussion among participants from the industrial, governmental, and academic sectors. The event was an excellent opportunity for students to learn about hot topics in mobile systems and applications, open research problems, and possible career options after graduation. We believe that the exposure to the technical content of HotMobile 2017 inspired students to address the tough problems in their respective field, with a long-­term benefit of scientific progress for mobile networks and systems. The requested travel funds allowed students conducting research in the field to attend high caliber technical presentations, be exposed to the state­-of­-the-­art research, and interact with leading researchers and fellow students, thereby making contacts potentially critical to their careers and future success. We expect the impact to the students’ careers from attending HotMobile 2017 to be substantial.
